Introduction

Local anesthetics temporarily block pain perception in a targeted area without impairing consciousness.  They work by inhibiting voltage-gated sodium channels in nerve cell membranes, thereby halting the transmission of sensory signals to the brain.  Local anesthetics have a wide range of clinical uses, from alleviating pain during minor procedures to providing regional anesthesia.  They are classified into 2 categories (amides and esters) based on their chemical structure, metabolism, and clinical characteristics.

Mechanism of action



Nerve impulses are transmitted by the rapid influx of sodium ions through voltage-gated sodium channels in neuronal membranes.  Local anesthetics reversibly block these voltage-gated sodium channels, preventing depolarization and halting the propagation of action potentials.  This interrupts the transmission of pain signals to the brain.  Sensory blockade occurs in a predictable sequence, beginning with the loss of pain perception, then temperature, touch, and pressure.



Local anesthetics are most effective on small, myelinated nerve fibers, although the fiber size plays a more significant role than myelination.  The order of nerve blockade generally follows this pattern:  Small, myelinated fibers are blocked first and are followed by small, unmyelinated fibers; then large, myelinated fibers; and, finally, large, unmyelinated fibers.  In addition, rapidly firing nerves (eg, pain fibers) are more susceptible to blockade because the anesthetic binds when the target nerve's sodium channel is open and active.

Pharmacokinetics



Local anesthetics are weak bases that exist in ionized and nonionized forms.  The nonionized form is lipid soluble and easily crosses the neuronal membrane.  When inside the neuron, the nonionized molecule acquires a proton (from a hydrogen ion) and becomes ionized.  The ionized form, which is water soluble, binds to and blocks the voltage-gated sodium channel (

figure 1
).

Onset of action



The ratio of ionized to nonionized molecules determines the onset of action.  Because only the nonionized, lipid-soluble form can readily cross the neuronal membrane, a higher proportion of nonionized molecules leads to a faster onset of action.



The proportion of ionized versus nonionized molecules is influenced by the pH of the surrounding environment and the pKa of the anesthetic, which is the pH at which 50% of the drug is ionized and 50% is nonionized.  Local anesthetics with a pKa closer to physiologic pH (7.4) have more nonionized molecules, resulting in a more rapid onset.



Acidic environments (eg, inflamed tissues) increase the proportion of ionized molecules, reducing the anesthetic's ability to penetrate nerve cells.  This delays onset and often requires higher anesthetic concentrations to achieve adequate nerve blockade.  Conversely, basic solutions favor the formation of nonionized molecules, so alkalinizing the anesthetic solution (eg, with bicarbonate) increases the onset of action.

Potency and duration of action



Local anesthetics that are more lipid soluble (eg, bupivacaine) are generally more potent because they can more easily diffuse across the neuronal membrane.  Lipid solubility also contributes to a longer duration of action because the anesthetic tends to accumulate in fatty tissues, which slows its clearance and extends its local effects.



The addition of a vasoconstrictor (eg, epinephrine [adrenaline]) to a local anesthetic solution prolongs the duration of action and increases the drug's effectiveness by reducing blood flow to the site of injection, which slows drug clearance.  Epinephrine also lowers the risk for systemic absorption by keeping the anesthetic confined to the injection area.  However, epinephrine use should be avoided in regions with smaller, end-arterial vessels (eg, fingers, nose, ears, toes, penis) due to a higher risk for ischemia in these areas.

Classification



Although all local anesthetics share a common mechanism of action, they are divided into 2 categories based on molecular structure.  Local anesthetics consist of a lipophilic aromatic ring and a tertiary amine, which are connected by an intermediate ester or amide linkage.  The ester or amide link determines the category of the anesthetic:



  • Esters (eg, procaine, tetracaine, benzocaine) are hydrolyzed by plasma cholinesterases, resulting in faster metabolism and a shorter duration of action.
  • Amides (eg, lidocaine, bupivacaine, ropivacaine) are metabolized by hepatic enzymes, which leads to slower metabolism and a longer duration of action.

Administration and clinical indications



Local anesthetics are used to anesthetize the skin, subcutaneous tissue, and peripheral nerves.  The route of administration depends on the intended effect or clinical indication:



  • Local infiltration:  Local anesthetic is injected directly into the target site, which is often a small area.  It is used for minor procedures (eg, sutures, abscess drainage).
  • Topical anesthesia:  Topical anesthesia is useful for anesthetizing the skin (eg, prior to intravenous placement), surface of the eye (eg, corneal abrasions), or mucous membranes (eg, stomatitis, pharyngitis).
  • Peripheral nerve blocks:  Anesthetic is injected near a specific nerve or nerve plexus to achieve anesthesia over a targeted region, such as a limb or dermatome.  Examples include an intercostal block for rib fracture (
    figure 2
    ), a digital block for finger/nail bed laceration (
    figure 3
    ), and a femoral nerve block for hip fracture.
  • Neuraxial anesthesia:
    • Spinal anesthesia:  Anesthetic is administered directly into the cerebrospinal fluid in the lumbar spine, typically for lower abdominal, pelvic (eg, cesarean delivery), or lower extremity surgeries.
    • Epidural anesthesia:  A catheter inserted into the epidural space delivers a continuous infusion of local anesthetic (eg, bupivacaine).  Epidural anesthesia is most often used to manage labor pain (
      figure 4
      ).
  • Chronic pain management (eg, nerve blocks for cancer or neuropathic pain).

Drug selection



Local anesthetics differ in their potency, onset, duration of action, and potential adverse effects, which makes certain agents better suited for specific clinical indications.  Commonly used local anesthetics include lidocaine, bupivacaine, benzocaine, and tetracaine.

Lidocaine



  • Class:  Amide.
  • Onset/duration:  Rapid onset (2-5 min) moderate duration (30-120 min).
  • Uses:  Most often used for local infiltration during minor procedures/dental work; also available in various topical formulations (eg, cream, viscous solutions, patch).
  • Adverse effects:  CNS toxicity and cardiovascular depression at high doses.

Bupivacaine



  • Class:  Amide.
  • Onset/duration:  Slower onset (15-30 min), long duration (5-10 hr or longer with epinephrine).
  • Uses:  Often used for postsurgical local anesthesia, neuraxial anesthesia, and peripheral nerve blocks due to its long duration of action.
  • Adverse effects:  High risk for severe cardiotoxicity (ventricular arrhythmias, cardiac arrest) with inadvertent intravascular injection or high doses.
  • Ropivacaine, another local anesthetic, is similar to bupivacaine but has a slightly different molecular structure, making it less potent but also less cardiotoxic.

Benzocaine



  • Class:  Ester.
  • Onset/duration:  Rapid onset (1-3 min), short duration (15-30 min).
  • Uses:  Primarily used for topical anesthesia of the oropharynx (eg, pharyngitis), anus (eg, hemorrhoids), and skin (eg, insect bite, burns).
  • Adverse effects:  Associated with methemoglobinemia, a condition in which hemoglobin loses its ability to carry oxygen effectively, resulting in cyanosis and hypoxia that are unresponsive to supplemental oxygen.  The exact mechanism is unclear but can be reversed with methylene blue (

Tetracaine



  • Class:  Ester.
  • Onset/duration:  Rapid onset (10-20 sec), short duration (10-20 min).
  • Uses:  Most frequently used for topical ocular anesthesia (eg, corneal abrasion, tonometry).
  • Adverse effects:  Prolonged, continuous use may lead to corneal epithelial toxicity.

Adverse effects

Allergic reactions



Allergic reactions to local anesthetics are rare but occur more often with ester-type anesthetics.  This is due to the production of paraaminobenzoic acid, an antigenic metabolite formed by the action of pseudocholinesterase.  Although less common, amide-type anesthetics can cause hypersensitivity reactions, primarily due to the preservative methylparaben.  If a patient has an allergic reaction to one class of local anesthetics, future use should be limited to the other class.

Local anesthetic systemic toxicity



Although local anesthetics are generally considered safe, they can cause systemic toxicity, particularly when administered in high doses or when inadvertently administered via intravascular injection.  The CNS and cardiovascular system are most susceptible to toxicity:



  • CNS manifestations:  Include perioral numbness, metallic taste, tinnitus, anxiety, twitching, dizziness, seizures, CNS depression, coma.
  • Cardiovascular collapse:  Typically follows the development of CNS symptoms.  Findings include hypotension, arrhythmias, heart block, and cardiac arrest (highest risk with bupivacaine).


Lipid emulsion therapy is first-line therapy, but extracorporeal membrane oxygenation may be needed in refractory cases.  Prevention strategies to avoid systemic toxicity include adhering to maximum dosing guidelines, using the lowest effective dose to achieve anesthesia, aspirating before injecting, and performing regional blocks under ultrasonographic guidance.

Summary



Local anesthetics are designed to alleviate pain in a specific location.  They are classified as esters or amides and act by inhibiting voltage-gated sodium channels in the neuronal membrane, thereby preventing pain signals from reaching the brain.  Local anesthetics have a wide range of clinical applications, providing both local and regional anesthesia.  Although generally well tolerated, excessive systemic absorption or accidental intravascular injection can cause serious toxicity involving the CNS and cardiovascular system.
